Review Methane reforming to synthesis gas over Ni catalysts modified with noble metals Dalin Li a b Yoshinao Nakagawa a Keiichi Tomishige a ⁎ a Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Tohoku University, 6-6-07, Aoba, Aramaki, Aoba-ku, Sendai 980-8579, Japan b National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst, Fuzhou University, Gongye Road 523, Fuzhou 350002, Fujian, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +81 22 795 7214; fax: +81 22 795 7214. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Addition of noble metals to Ni catalysts gives noble metal–Ni bimetallic particles. ► The structure of bimetallic particles is influenced by the preparation method. ► Noble metal–modified Ni catalysts show high performances by the synergetic effect. ► Activity, stability, hot spot, activation, and regeneration properties are improved. Nickel is an effective component for the steam reforming of methane in terms of the catalytic activity and the catalyst cost. When Ni catalysts are applied to dry reforming, oxidative reforming, and catalytic partial oxidation, it is necessary to add the properties of high resistance to oxidation, hot spot formation, and coke deposition, to the Ni catalysts. An efficient method for giving these properties while considering the catalyst cost is the modification of Ni metal particles with small amounts of noble metals. An important point is that preparation methods can affect the structure of noble metal–Ni bimetallic particles, which is connected to the catalytic performances. The additive effects of noble metals on the catalytic performances are summarized in terms of activity, suppression of Ni oxidation, carbon formation, self-activation, and sustainability in the daily startup and shutdown operations. Keywords Methane reforming, Synthesis gas, Ni catalyst, Noble metal, Ni oxidation, Hot spot, Carbon formation, Self-activation, Daily startup and shut down 1 Introduction Production of synthesis gas from natural gas is one of the important technologies in the chemical industry because the synthesis gas can be converted to useful liquid fuels and chemicals such as Fischer–Tropsch oil, methanol, and dimethyl ether [1–4]. Hydrogen is practically produced from natural gas, and the produced hydrogen is mainly used for the ammonia synthesis [1,5,6]. In particular, much attention has been paid to the hydrogen production relating to the fuel cell technology [7–9]. Reforming reactions of methane, which is the main component of natural gas, play a key in the production of synthesis gas and hydrogen from natural gas. It is known that methane reforming has two major types, i.e., steam reforming and carbon dioxide reforming. The latter is also called as dry reforming. (1) CH4 +H2O→CO+3H2,ΔH 298K°=+206kJmol−1 (2) CH4 +CO2 →2CO+2H2,ΔH 298K°=+286kJmol−1 Steam reforming of methane (Eq. (1)) gives synthesis gas with high H2 to CO ratio (H2/CO), and dry reforming of methane (Eq. (2)) gives the gas with lower H2 to CO ratio. As is known, the combination of steam reforming with dry reforming enables the adjustment of H2/CO of the produced synthesis gas [3,10,11]. In the practical process of methane reforming for the large-scale gas-to-liquid and small-scale fuel cell technologies, tubular reactors have been applied. Since both steam and dry reforming of methane are highly endothermic reactions, as indicated above (Eqs. (1) and (2)), it is necessary to supply the heat to the reactor tube from the reactor outside with a combustion reaction (Eq. (3)) [3,6,12]. (3) CH4 +2O2 →CO2 +2H2O,ΔH 298K°=−806kJmol−1 Both steam and CO2 reforming of methane are reversible and methane conversion and the effluent gas composition are controlled by the reaction equilibrium. High temperature (for example, higher than 1073K) at the catalyst bed is needed for high methane conversion. This demands the heat resistant catalysts. It has been pointed out that one problem in methane reforming is carbon deposition on the catalyst surface, which causes the catalyst deactivation, plugging of the reactor, and breakdown of the catalyst granules [3,13–15]. There are two major routes for the carbon formation. One is methane decomposition (Eq. (4)) and the other is CO disproportionation (Eq. (5)) [3,13–15]. (4) CH4 →C+2H2,ΔH 298K°=+75kJmol−1 (5) 2CO→C+CO2,ΔH 298K°=−172kJmol−1 The tendency of carbon deposition can be expected by the atomic ratios of O/C and H/C in the feed gas. Lower O/C and H/C ratios correspond to higher tendency toward carbon deposition [16]. In the stoichiometric steam reforming of methane (H2O/CH4 =1/1), O/C and H/C ratios are calculated to be 1 and 6, respectively. In fact, in the industrial steam reforming of methane, the partial pressure of steam is higher than the stoichiometry, for example H2O/CH4 =2/1 (O/C=2, H/C=8) [1,5]. This is because stable operation is difficult over the conventional steam reforming catalyst at H2O/CH4 =1/1 due to the carbon deposition. In contrast, in the stoichiometric dry reforming of methane (CO2/CH4 =1/1), O/C and H/C ratios are calculated to be 1 and 2, respectively, which are much lower than those in the steam reforming of methane. This means that the tendency of carbon deposition in the dry reforming of methane is much higher than that in the steam reforming of methane [17]. In addition, it has been reported that the increase of total pressure remarkably enhances the carbon deposition tendency [5,17,18]. A large-scale synthesis gas production method with higher energy efficiency than steam reforming of methane is required. Since the endothermic heat due to reforming reactions is supplied from the reactor outside, the reaction rate is limited by the heat transfer. Therefore, higher productivity cannot be realized by the increase of the reactor tube diameter, but by the increase of the reactor tube number. The scale merit of the syngas production by this method is low. Oxygen-blown ATR (autothermal reforming) has recently been the preferred technology for large-scale GTL plants [19]. ATR is cheaper than steam reforming because of a more favorable economy of scale for oxygen plants than for the tubular reformer. In the ATR process, oxygen is fed together with natural gas and steam. The added oxygen engenders exothermic reactions such as non-catalytic partial oxidation (CH4 +1/2O2 →CO+2H2) and combustion of methane using a burner in the non-catalytic reaction zone; this heat is supplied for the catalytic reforming reaction on the catalysts. Here, the contact between the reforming catalysts with oxygen is inhibited to suppress hot spot formation. Hot spot formation is a common problem in the reforming of hydrocarbons to synthesis gas using oxygen as mentioned below, especially for monometallic Ni catalysts [20,21]. The ATR process is adiabatic and needs no external heating, so it enables high productivity using a large single reactor. Oxidative reforming of methane, in which O2 is introduced to the catalyst bed together with methane, steam and CO2, is a promising method for synthesis gas production because the reaction conditions can be adjusted to those of an autothermal system [22–24]. In the oxidative reforming process, exothermic combustion on the catalyst surface is combined with endothermic reforming. Oxidative steam reforming of methane can also be more energy-efficient than conventional steam reforming of methane like the ATR process. Problems of the oxidative reforming include deactivation by oxidation, hot spot formation and carbon deposition [23,24]. As explained below, oxidative reforming of methane consists of the oxidizing atmosphere near the catalyst bed inlet and the reducing atmosphere downstream in the bed. The oxidizing atmosphere is due to the presence of O2 in the gas phase, and the reducing atmosphere is due to the absence of O2. In the oxidizing region, exothermic oxidation reactions proceed and they enhance the catalyst bed temperature, which is connected to hot spot formation. The oxidative reforming of methane will be more feasible after the development of catalysts with high resistance to hot spot formation. In the ATR process and oxidative reforming of methane, some equipment for the oxygen production from air is needed, particularly in the case of GTL and methanol synthesis. This is because the reaction of Fischer–Tropsch [25–27] and methanol syntheses [28–30] has been carried out under high pressure of synthesis gas. When air is used in the synthesis gas production process, the partial pressure of the produced synthesis gas is decreased by the presence of nitrogen. The high cost for the equipment of the oxygen production is compensated by the effect of the high pressure of synthesis gas in the large-scale plant. The utilization of oxygen in the synthesis gas production method with smaller scale for the fuel cell system becomes more feasible by more economical oxygen production. In recent decades, much attention has been paid to the technology for hydrogen production using the reforming reaction with much smaller scale than the GTL and methanol plants, in relation to the fuel cell technology [7–9]. The operation time of the fuel cell process is much shorter than that of large plants, and daily startup and shutdown (DSS) operations are often carried out. Therefore, catalytic performance should be maintained during the operation including DSS [8,31]. In particular, the daily startup procedure includes the catalyst activation, and the DSS procedure can accelerate the catalyst deactivation via oxidation and sintering [32,33]. The resistance to the DSS operation should be added to the catalysts. It is well known that methane is one of the most stable hydrocarbon molecules and it has lower reactivity than other hydrocarbons. Therefore, the dissociation of the C–H bond is an important step in the activation of methane, which is catalyzed by the surfaces of various metals. The reaction order regarding the partial pressure of methane in the dissociative adsorption of methane over noble-metal surface is lower than 1.0, such as 0.6, when the methane molecules with higher translational and vibrational energy using molecular beam technique were applied [34,35]. However, in most cases, the low reactivity of methane is connected to the first reaction order with respect to the partial pressure of methane in the steam and dry reforming of methane [36]. Reforming of methane with steam and CO2 is catalyzed by various base and noble metals such as Ni, Co, Ru, Rh, Pd, Pt and so on. The order of the catalytic activity of metal catalysts supported on Al2O3-MgO was reported to be Ru>Rh>Ir>Ni>Pt [37]. Pt clusters also show the most reactive surfaces for the C–H bond activation compared to Ir, Ni, Rh and Ru catalysts supported on various oxides [36]. The activity order per the surface site has not agreed well in various reports; however, important points are that Ni has a comparable activity to noble-metal catalysts, and that the higher loading amount of Ni is feasible in terms of the catalyst cost in order to increase the activity per the volume of the catalyst. However, Ni is inferior to noble metals regarding the resistance to carbon deposition and catalyst oxidation, and the ability of the catalyst activation [17,24,38,39]. In fact, noble metals have a problem in the limited availability and high cost, and noble metals are not utilized practically unless the loading amount of noble metals is much smaller than that of Ni. This review article is related to the attempts to give high resistance to carbon deposition and catalyst oxidation and to give high ability of catalyst activation to Ni catalysts by the addition of very small amounts of noble metals. Table 1 lists some examples of the catalysts for methane reforming and the additive effect of noble metals [40–94]. 2 Preparation and structure of Ni metal particles modified with small amounts of noble metals 2.1 Ni metal particles modified with noble metals supported on γ-Al2O3 When metal catalysts modified with much smaller amounts of another metal are prepared, we have to pay much attention to the preparation method in order to bring out high catalytic performances for the modified catalysts. A typical preparation method is the co-impregnation method using an aqueous solution containing two precursors. Sequential (two-step) impregnation method is another candidate for the preparation. Structural differences of the catalysts prepared by the co-impregnation and the sequential impregnation methods are described using Pd–Ni/γ-Al2O3 as an example [79,80,85–87]. A commercially available γ-Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-1) (Catalysis Society of Japan, S BET =143m2 g−1, grain size of 2–3mm) was calcined at 1123K in air for 3h; it was used as a support material. The resulting support had a specific surface area of 110m2 g−1. It was crushed and sieved to particle sizes between 180 and 250μm before impregnation. Supported monometallic Ni and Pd catalysts were prepared using the impregnation method with the aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and PdCl2, respectively. After removal of the solvent by heating and evaporation at 353K, the resulting product was dried in an oven at 383K for 12h. Subsequently, the sample was calcined at 773K in air for 3h. Bimetallic catalysts (Pd–Ni) were prepared using two methods. One is the sequential impregnation method. The calcined monometallic nickel catalyst was reduced at 1123K for 0.5h under H2 flow, and then the treated sample was impregnated with the acetone solution of Pd(C5H7O2)2 under air atmosphere. After removal of the acetone solvent, the catalyst was dried at 383K for 12h and calcined in air at 573K for 3h. The resultant catalyst is denoted as Pd/Ni. The other method is co-impregnation. The precursor solution is a mixed aqueous one of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and PdCl2. After co-impregnation, the sample was dried at 383K for 12h, followed by calcination at 773K in air for 3h. This resultant catalyst is denoted as Pd+Ni. All catalysts were reduced in the H2 flow at 1123K for 0.5h prior to activity tests. The numbers in parentheses refer to the weight percent of the catalyst's metallic component. Different Pd precursors are used in these two preparation methods. In the case of the sequential impregnation, we were afraid that the oxidized and metallic Ni species would be soluble to the acidic Pd solution. During the reduction pretreatment, the metallic particles are formed. Temperature-programmed reduction profiles gave useful information on the additive effect of noble metals. Since the reducibility of noble metals is much higher than that of Ni species, noble metal addition can promote the reduction of Ni species [95]. Fig. 1 (A) shows the temperature-programmed reduction profiles of Ni(0.9), Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9), and Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9) supported on γ-Al2O3 [85]. If we judge from the very low molar ratio of Pd to Ni (Pd/Ni=1/17), most H2 consumption is due to the reduction of Ni species. The Ni species on Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9) are more reducible than those on Ni(0.9). The Ni species on Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9) have very high reducibility. In-situ quick-scanning EXAFS (QXAFS) analysis gave us the information on the reduction of Pd species. Fig. 1(B) and (C) shows the temperature dependences of the coordination numbers of Pd–O, Pd–Pd, and Pd–Ni bonds on Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9) and Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9) in the in situ QXAFS analysis [85]. The coordination number of the Pd–O bond (CNPd–O) almost disappeared on both catalysts at 433K, at the same time, the CNPd–Pd increased drastically. This indicates that the Pd species on Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9) and Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9) are similar and that the reduction profiles of the Pd species are also similar. In addition, it is clear that the CNPd–Pd at 433K was much smaller than 12, which is the CN of bulk Pd metal, if one consider the contributions of small CNPd–O. This also indicates the formation of highly dispersed Pd metal clusters. At 563K, the CNPd–Pd on Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9) decreased more significantly than that on Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9). At this temperature, the Ni species on Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9) started to be reduced, in contrast, the Ni species on Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9) were not reduced. Therefore, the difference in CNPd–Pd at 563K is caused by the different states of Ni species. At higher reduction temperature, the CNPd–Pd on both catalysts was not changed drastically. An important point is the behavior of Pd–Ni bonds. At 663K, most Ni species on Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9) were already reduced; in contrast, most Ni species on Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9) were not reduced yet. However, the contribution of CNPd–Ni on Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9) was higher than that on Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9). In addition, the coordination number ratio of CNPd–Ni/(CNPd–Pd +CNPd–Ni) on Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9) is much higher than that on Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9). The coordination number ratio of CNPd–Ni/(CNPd–Pd +CNPd–Ni) is reflected by the degree of mixture in the Pd–Ni bimetallic particles which are formed during the reduction. In the case of Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9), the reduction of Ni species proceeds by the incorporation into small Pd metal particles of the highly dispersed Ni species that interact with γ-Al2O3 surface. In contrast, in the case of Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9), the interaction between Ni species and γ-Al2O3 surface is weakened during the preparation procedure and NiO particles are formed as described below. Therefore, the reduction of Ni species can proceed without the incorporation of Ni into Pd metal particles. Furthermore, the CNPd–Pd +CNPd–Ni on both catalysts was much smaller than 12, indicating that the ratio of surface Pd atoms on the metal particles is high. Table 2 lists the Pd K-edge EXAFS analysis of the Pd–Ni bimetallic catalysts after the reduction as mentioned above [85]. On Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9)/γ-Al2O3, the presence of the Pd–Ni bond without the detection of the Pd–Pd bond indicates that the Pd metal atoms are highly dispersed in the Ni metal particles. This tendency is also suggested by the high coordination number ratio of CNPd–Ni/(CNPd–Pd +CNPd–Ni) in the results of in situ QXAFS during the reduction (Fig. 1C). In the reduction process, Pd metal particles are formed at first, and then highly (atomically) dispersed Ni ion species on γ-Al2O3 are incorporated into Pd metal particles and reduced to metallic Ni. This is connected to the breaking of the Pd–Pd bonds and the formation of Pd–Ni bond. At higher reduction temperature, the ratio of Pd atoms in the Pd–Ni bimetallic particles becomes relatively smaller, and the contribution of the Pd–Pd bond is negligible. As a result, well-mixed Pd–Ni alloy particles are formed on Pd(0.1)+Ni(0.9)/γ-Al2O3. On the other hand, the presence of the Pd–Pd bond as well as the Pd–Ni bond on Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9)/γ-Al2O3, is related to the low coordination number ratio of CNPd–Ni/(CNPd–Pd +CNPd–Ni) in the in situ QXAFS result (Fig. 1C). One possible interpretation of the small coordination number ratio of CNPd–Ni/(CNPd–Pd +CNPd–Ni) on Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9) is that the Pd–Ni bonds are present between the Ni metal particles and very small Pd metal particles. Fig. 2 shows the temperature-programmed reduction profiles of Pt(0.2)/Ni(0.9), Pt(0.2)+Ni(0.9) and related catalysts, which are prepared in the similar way to the case of Pd–Ni [87]. The TPR results are also similar. Here, Ni(0.9) after the reduction at 1123K and the subsequent calcination at 573K is also shown, and the reduction procedure forms Ni metal particles and then the subsequent calcination causes the oxidation of Ni metal particles to NiO oxide particles. The high reduction temperature in the TPR results on Ni(0.9) is due to highly dispersed Ni ion species interacting with γ-Al2O3 surfaces, and the low reduction temperature on Ni(0.9) after the reduction at 1123K and the subsequent calcination at 573K is assigned to larger NiO particles formed on the γ-Al2O3 surfaces. In addition, the addition of Pt promoted the reduction of NiO further. The promoting effect of noble metals on the reduction of Ni species can be interpreted by the hydrogen spillover phenomenon. On the metallic surface, H2 molecules dissociate to hydrogen species, which are diffused to different species via the support surface [96–98]. The formation mechanism of noble metal–Ni bimetallic particles influences the surface segregation of noble-metal atoms. Temperature-programmed reduction and in situ EXAFS as described above give little information about the surface of bimetallic particles. In order to get this information, we carried out the EXAFS analysis of the catalysts after the passivation and the FTIR observation of CO adsorption as a probe of surface atom determination. Table 3 lists the curve fitting results of the Ni K-edge EXAFS spectra of Pt(0.2)/Ni(0.9) and Pt(0.2)+Ni(0.9) supported on γ-Al2O3 after the reduction and passivation (the oxidation of the surface with low-concentration oxygen) at room temperature [87]. In the case of Pt(0.2)+Ni(0.9), the CN of the Ni–Ni bond decreased remarkably with the passivation procedure, which is due to the breaking of the Ni–Ni bonds by the oxidation. On the other hand, the CN of the Ni–Ni bond on Pt(0.2)/Ni(0.9) was not changed by the oxidation, and this means that metal particles on Pt(0.2)/Ni(0.9) have resistance to the oxidation. This suggests the surface segregation of Pt atoms on the bimetallic Pt–Ni particles. It was verified that the size of the metal particle size on Pt(0.2)/Ni(0.9) was similar to that on Pt(0.2)+Ni(0.9), indicating that the difference in the resistance to the oxidation cannot be explained by the metal particle size. The FTIR spectra of CO adsorption were measured to characterize surface properties of Pt–Ni bimetallic particles; Fig. 3 shows the results [87]. The bands at 2070cm−1 and 2048cm−1 on the monometallic Ni catalyst (Ni(2.6)) are attributable to the linear CO on Ni metal [99,100]; the band at about 1940cm−1 is assigned to the bridge CO [101]. Only one band at 2070cm−1 was observed on the monometallic Pt catalyst (Pt(0.1)); this band is assigned to linear CO [102–104]. Two broad bands at 2070 and 2048cm−1 with similar intensity were observed in the case of Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6). The bands resembled those of Ni(2.6). In contrast, for Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6), the intensity of the 2070cm−1 band was much stronger than that of the 2048cm−1 band. The difference in the spectra between Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) and Ni(2.6) is attributable to the intensity of the 2070cm−1 band, which may be caused by linear CO on Pt. Judging from the FTIR of CO adsorption, we conclude that the Pt atoms are located on the surface of metal particles more preferentially on the catalyst prepared by the sequential impregnation method. The mechanism of the formation of the bimetallic particles prepared by two different methods is described in Fig. 4 on the basis of the above characterization results. Very small Pd clusters on Pd(0.1)/Ni(0.9) are located on the surface of bimetallic particles. 2.2 Ni metal particles modified with noble metals supported on α-Al2O3 and NiO–MgO solid solutions The comparison between the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts modified with small amount of noble metals by two different preparation methods (the sequential impregnation and co-impregnation methods) indicates that the structure of bimetallic particles is strongly influenced by the precursor state of Ni species, and that the NiO oxide particles are more preferable for the preparation of the bimetallic particles with the surface segregation of noble-metal atoms than the highly dispersed Ni species. The interaction of Ni species with α-Al2O3 is not as strong as that with γ-Al2O3. Ni catalysts supported on α-Al2O3 modified with noble metals were prepared [83,84]. The α-Al2O3 support (8m2 g−1) was prepared by the calcination of JRC-ALO-1 (provided by Catalysis Society of Japan, 143m2 g−1, grain size of 2–3mm) in air at 1423K for 3h. It was crushed and sieved to particle sizes between 180 and 250mm before impregnation. Supported monometallic Ni catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method using an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. Supported monometallic noble-metal catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method using an aqueous solution of PdCl2, H2PtCl6·6H2O, HAuCl4·4H2O, H2IrCl6, RhCl3·3H2O, and RuCl3·nH2O. After removal of the solvent by heating and evaporation at 353K, the resulting product was dried in an oven at 383K for 12h. Subsequently, the sample was calcined at 773K in air for 3h. Bimetallic catalysts were prepared by the co-impregnation method using mixed aqueous solutions of the precursors. After co-impregnation, the preparation procedure is identical to that of monometallic catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the temperature-programmed reduction profiles of Ni(10.6)/α-Al2O3 samples modified with small amounts of noble metals, which were prepared by the co-impregnation method [83]. The reduction of the Ni species on Ni(10.6) proceeded in the temperature range of 623–923K, which was much lower than the reduction of the Ni species on γ-Al2O3. The H2 consumption peak was shifted to lower temperature by the addition of noble metals, and this indicates that the addition of noble metals enhanced the reducibility of Ni species. The order of the catalyst reducibility is as follows: Pt(0.4)+Ni(10.6)>Pd(0.2)+Ni(10.6)>Rh(0.2)+Ni(10.6)>Ru(0.2)+Ni(10.6)>Ir(0.4)+Ni(10.6)>Au(0.4)+Ni(10.6)>Ni(10.6). According to the results of the temperature profile in the catalyst bed during the reaction in the oxidative steam reforming of methane, the addition of small amount of noble metals by the co-impregnation method is effective for the suppression of the hot spot formation, which is related to the presence of noble-metal atoms on the surface of bimetallic particles [83]. The EXAFS result of Pd(0.2)+Ni(10.6)/α-Al2O3 indicates a larger coordination number ratio of CNPd–Pd/CNPd–Ni than in the case of two γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts in spite of the lower molar ratio of Pd to Ni (Table 2) [83]. The formation of Pd metal particles at the first step in the reduction process is expected and the size of the Pd metal particles on α-Al2O3 can be much larger than that on γ-Al2O3. Based on this expectation, the Pd-cluster–embedded Ni metal particles are formed on Pd(0.2)+Ni(10.6)/α-Al2O3 as illustrated in Fig. 6 (a). Next, we consider the additive effect of noble metals to NiO–MgO solid solution catalysts. The interaction between Ni species and MgO is so strong that NiO–MgO solid solution is formed, and the reducibility of NiO–MgO is lower than that of Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/α-Al2O3 [105]. Ni0.2Mg0.8O solid solution was prepared by the solid reaction method from NiO and MgO [72–75,77,78]. The mixture of NiO with MgO was calcined in air at 1423K for 12h. The formation of Ni0.2Mg0.8O solid solution was identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD). After the calcination, the BET surface area of Ni0.2Mg0.8O was determined to be 2.6m2 g−1. As a reference, MgO was calcined at the same temperature and the BET surface area of MgO was determined to be 5.7m2 g−1. The loading of Pd on Ni0.2Mg0.8O and MgO was performed by the impregnation of Ni0.2Mg0.8O and MgO with aqueous solutions of Pd(NO3)2. After removal of the solvent by heating, the catalysts were dried overnight at 383K and then calcined in air at 773K for 3h. The loading amount of Pd is in the parentheses. Fig. 7 shows the temperature-programmed reduction profiles of Pd(0.1, 0.5)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O and related catalysts [73]. Hydrogen consumption was observed above about 523K over Ni0.2Mg0.8O, and the consumption amount was increased by the addition of Pd, although the reduction started at a similar temperature. On Pd(0.5)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O, the peak at 353K was also observed in the same manner as that on Pd(0.5)/MgO, indicating the reduction of Pd. In fact, the amount of hydrogen consumption was much smaller than the loading amount of Pd. This is due to the reduction of Pd during the purging of the reactor cell with hydrogen at room temperature. The molar ratios of Pd to reduced Ni are calculated to be 0.05 and 0.20 on Pd(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O and Pd(0.5)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O, respectively [73]. From the Pd K-edge EXAFS analysis of Pd(0.5)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O listed in Table 2 [73], we find that the CN ratio of CNPd–Pd/CNPd–Ni is much higher than that on Pd(0.2)+Ni(10.6)/α-Al2O3. This is interpreted as due to the large size of Pd metal phase in the Pd-cluster–embedded Ni metal particles (Fig. 6(b)). The size of Pd metal particles formed at the first step in the reduction process becomes larger because NiO–MgO solid solution has lower reducibility than NiO supported on α-Al2O3, judging from the TPR profiles, and so the aggregation of Pd metal particles proceeds at higher temperature without the interaction with Ni species. It should be noted that the much higher molar ratio of Pd to reduced Ni (Pd/Ni0) on Pd(0.5)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O than that on Pd(0.2)+Ni(10.6)/α-Al2O3 can also be related to the increase of the ratio of CNPd–Pd/CNPd–Ni. From the viewpoint of the additive effect, noble-metal atoms should be located near the surface. The presence of the Pd atoms on the surface can be verified by FTIR of the CO adsorption. Fig. 8 shows FTIR spectra of CO adsorption on reduced Ni0.2Mg0.8O, Pd/Ni0.2Mg0.8O and Pd/MgO catalysts [73]. In the case of Ni0.2Mg0.8O, we observed two peaks; one at 2050cm−1 due to linear CO on Ni and the other at 1940cm−1 due to bridging CO species on Ni [106]. One characteristic is that the intensity of bridging CO is relatively strong compared to that of linear CO over Ni0.2Mg0.8O. However, the CO adsorption profile was drastically changed when Pd was added on Ni0.2Mg0.8O. On Pd/Ni0.2Mg0.8O catalysts, one new peak at 1980cm−1 appeared. As a reference, the spectrum of Pd/MgO is also shown in Fig. 8. According to the previous reports, the peak at 1970cm−1 is assigned to bridging CO on Pd and the peak at 1900cm−1 is assigned to CO adsorbed on the three-fold hollow site of Pd surface [107–109]. From the comparison with Pd/MgO, the peak that appeared on Pd/Ni0.2Mg0.8O at 1968cm−1 can be assigned to bridging CO on Pd. The intensity of this peak increased with increasing Pd content in Pd/Ni0.2Mg0.8O. This supports the presence of Pd particles on the surface of the Pd-cluster–embedded Ni metal particles, as illustrated in Fig. 6(b). 2.3 Ni metal particles modified with noble metals supported on other supports Li et al. [57–61] have prepared various noble metal-doped Ni/Mg(Al)O catalysts by adopting the “memory effect” of Mg–Al hydrotalcite (HT). In these studies, Mg(Ni)–Al hydrotalcite was prepared by coprecipitation and calcined to form Mg(Ni,Al)O periclase. When Mg(Ni,Al)O periclase was dipped in an aqueous solution of noble-metal nitrate, the HT was reconstituted due to the “memory effect”. During the reconstitution, noble-metal ions were incorporated or trapped in the layer structure of the HT, which led to the formation of highly dispersed noble metal–Ni supported catalysts after the calcination, followed by the reduction. EXAFS studies of Ru-doped Ni/Mg(Al)O catalysts after the reduction confirm the formation of Ru-Ni alloy particles where the Ru is located in the surface layer of Ni metal particles [59]. A similar noble-metal location was also observed for Rh- and Pt-Ni/Mg(Al)O; Pt is more deeply incorporated into Ni particles than Ru and Rh on Ru-Ni/Mg(Al)O and Rh-Ni/Mg(Al)O [61]. By using co-precipitation, Nagaoka et al. [88] prepared a NiRh/MgAl bimetallic catalyst from a hydrotalcite precursor, in which a part of Mg2+ and Al3+ was replaced by Ni2+ and Rh3+, respectively. It was reported that NiRh alloy particles are formed and that the surface of the NiRh alloy particles is enriched in Ni, as confirmed by EXAFS and IR of adsorbed CO. Crisafulli et al. [43] prepared SiO2 supported Ni–Ru and Ni–Pd bimetallic catalysts from nitrate and chloride precursors by incipient wet co-impregnation. Ni(NO3)2 was used as the Ni precursor, and the nitrate or chloride salts were used as precursors of Ru and Pd. In the case of Ni–Ru catalysts, a strong Ni–Ru interaction takes place with formation of Ni–Ru bimetallic particles that have a surface mainly covered by Ni. The amount of Ni on the surface is lower for the chloride Ni–Ru catalyst than that for the nitrate Ni–Ru catalyst, probably due to the formation of larger clusters of Ru on the chloride samples, limiting the dispersion of nickel. On the other hand, in the case of Ni–Pd catalysts, the interaction between Ni and Pd is rather low and these metals tend to form separate aggregates. The formation of separate metallic aggregates is also suggested by Crisafulli et al. when H-ZSM5 is used as a support for Ni–Ru bimetallic catalysts [44]. The weak Ni–Ru interaction on H-ZSM5 supported catalysts is probably due to a strong metal–support interaction, which somewhat hinders the possibility of the formation of bimetallic phase. 3 Activity Table 4 lists the results of the activity test of Pt(0.1), Ni(2.6), Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6), Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) supported on γ-Al2O3 in the steam reforming of methane, and characterization results are also shown [23]. The activity of methane steam reforming of Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6) was comparable to that of Ni(2.6), and Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) has lower activity than Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6) and Ni(2.6). Metal particle sizes of Ni(2.6), Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6) and Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) were almost the same, and the difference of activity can be due to the surface composition. As mentioned in the previous section, Pt atoms are well-mixed with Ni on Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6), and the surface concentration of Pt is low, and Ni is the main component on the surface; these factors can explain the comparable activity of Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6) to that of Ni(2.6). Based on the result that Pt atoms are segregated to the surface on Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6), lower activity can be caused by the surface Pt atoms. In fact, the small Pt clusters may exhibit the high activity, but it is thought that the surface Pt atoms on Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6) become less active than the surface Ni atoms on much larger particles. Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) showed lower activity in the steam reforming of methane; in contrast, it showed higher performance in the oxidative steam reforming of methane as mentioned below [87]. Luna et al. [66] reported that the addition of small amounts of Rh to Ni/Al2O3 catalysts increased the number of metal atoms exposed on the surface. The activity of methane steam reforming was proportional to the number of metal surface atoms, and this means that the turnover frequencies were almost constant for promoted and unpromoted catalysts and that the apparent activation energy was unchanged. We conclude that Rh acts as a dispersion promoter for Ni. Foletto et al. [65] reported that the addition of small amounts of Pt to Ni/MgAl2O4 by the sequential impregnation method promoted an increase in surface area of Ni metal and caused a considerable increase in methane conversion in the steam reforming of methane. The addition of Pt, Pd and Rh to Ni0.03Mg0.97O solid solution catalyst enhanced the activity and stability in the methane reforming with CO2. The addition of noble metals increased the reduction degree of Ni species in the solid solution and the amount of H2 adsorption; the results suggest the formation of noble-metal alloy. The surface of the alloy particles gives higher turnover frequency than that of monometallic Ni metal particles. The kinetic analysis suggests that the alloy formation facilitate the methane dissociation. In addition, the addition of noble metals suppresses the coke formation [40,41,110]. Rh-promoted Ni/α-Al2O3 catalysts prepared by a co-impregnation method were reported to show higher activity than Ni/α-Al2O3 and Rh/α-Al2O3 catalysts and to exhibit excellent coke resistance ability in methane reforming with CO2 [49]. Becerra et al. [42] reported that the addition of small amounts of Rh to Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by a sequential impregnation method produces an increase in the metal surface area, accompanied by an increase of the methane dry reforming rate. However, the Rh addition has no influence on the turnover frequencies, suggesting that the activity increase is predominantly caused by the increase of the number of active sites rather than by the electronic effect. Crisafulli et al. [43] studied the effect of noble-metal addition (Ru,Pd) to Ni/SiO2 catalysts, which were prepared by co-impregnation method, for the CO2 reforming of methane. It was found that the catalytic behavior of the Ni–Ru and Ni–Pd bimetallic catalysts strongly depends both on the noble metal and the precursor used. In the case of Ni-based bimetallic samples prepared from nitrate precursors of the noble metal, the presence of Ru strongly improved the catalytic activity and stability. The addition of Pd to supported Ni catalyst caused just a slight increase in the reaction rate; however, the deactivation rate is higher than that observed on the monometallic Ni catalyst. On Ni-based bimetallic samples prepared starting from the chloride precursors, the presence of the noble metal (Ru or Pd) causes a moderate decrease in the catalytic activity. The best results in terms of activity and stability are obtained on the nitrate-derived Ni–Ru catalyst. The different catalytic performance between Ni–Ru and Ni–Pd bimetallic catalysts is mainly related to the different degrees of metal-metal interactions occurring on the catalysts. The strong improvements in the activity and stability observed in the case of ex-nitrate Ni–Ru catalysts has been attributed to the formation of Ni–Ru bimetallic clusters with a surface mainly covered by nickel. This leads to an increase in the metallic dispersion of Ni and favors the formation of a more reactive intermediate carbonaceous species, thus inhibiting the deactivation of the catalyst. In a later study [44], Crisafulli et al. compared the catalytic performance of SiO2 and H-ZSM zeolite supported Ni–Ru bimetallic catalysts in the CO2 reforming of methane. Ni–Ru/SiO2 catalysts are much active and stable than Ni–Ru/H-ZSM catalysts. The strong improvement in the activity and stability observed on SiO2 supported Ni–Ru bimetallic catalysts has been attributed to an increase in the dispersion of Ni metal as a consequence of the formation of Ni–Ru clusters with the surface mainly covered by Ni. Pawelec et al. [45] investigated the effect of the preparation method and the Ni content on the surface and catalytic properties of PtNi/ZSM-5 for the dry reforming of methane. Pt(0.5)/Ni(6) prepared by sequential impregnation was reported to exhibit the best performance in terms of activity and stability. The addition of Pt leads to the formation of small and easily reducible NiO particles. The improvements of catalytic activity and stability for Pt(0.5)/Ni(6) catalyst were attributed to an increase of the Ni metal dispersion caused by the intimate contact between Ni and Pt. Ni/MCM-41 catalysts modified with a small amount of Pd are also reported by Pawelec et al. to show high activity and stability in the dry reforming of methane [46]. The superior catalytic performance of Pd-promoted Ni catalyst is attributed to the synergy effect between Ni and Pd, which leads to high reduction degree and high metallic surface area due to increase of the dispersion. In a recent study by Özkara-Aydinoğlu et al. [51], it was reported that the catalytic performance of Pt/Ni/δ-Al2O3 in the dry reforming of methane strongly depended on the metal loadings and Pt/Ni ratio. Among all the catalysts, Pt(0.3)/Ni(10)/Al2O3 with the highest Pt/Ni ratio exhibited the highest catalytic activity and stability. We suggest that the high Pt/Ni ratio of Pt(0.3)/Ni(10)/Al2O3 led to a relatively easy reduction of NiO and to smaller-sized Ni particles due to the intimate interaction between Pt and Ni. 4 Suppression of Ni oxidation and promotion of Ni reduction 4.1 Suppression of deactivation due to oxidation of Ni metals The addition of noble metals to Ni catalyst can enhance the catalytic activity by the direct increase of the number of surface Ni atoms. Another additive effect is to increase the conversion by the enhancement of the catalyst reducibility. This behavior has been observed remarkably in the oxidative reforming of methane. Fig. 9 shows the additive effect of the gases for the combustion reaction (CH4/O2 = x/2x; x =2–10), which is called as the combustion gas, to methane steam reforming gas (CH4/H2O=30/30) on methane conversion over Ni(2.6), Pt(0.1), and Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) supported on γ-Al2O3 [86]. In this experiment, the partial pressure condition of A corresponds to the steam reforming of methane without the addition of oxygen. The order of methane conversion at A is as follows: Ni(2.6)>Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6)>Pt(0.1) as mentioned in Table 4. At this partial pressure condition, methane conversion at the reaction equilibrium is 92%. Methane conversion decreased drastically over Ni(2.6), which was comparable to the conversion given by the combustion reaction when the combustion gas was introduced. This behavior is interpreted as due to the deactivation of Ni metal species. Methane conversion over Pt(0.1) was low in steam reforming of methane. However, the addition of the combustion gas enhanced methane conversion. Methane conversion at F (oxidative steam reforming) over Pt(0.1) was much higher than that over Ni(2.6). This high activity of Pt(0.1) in oxidative steam reforming can be related to the high reducibility of Pt compared to Ni. Although methane conversion on Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) at the A condition was located between Ni(2.6) and Pt(0.1), the highest methane conversion was given by Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) at the F condition. Modification of Ni with Pt by sequential impregnation method enhanced the performance in the oxidative steam reforming of methane through inhibition of Ni oxidation. Fig. 10 shows the contact time (W/F) dependence of methane conversion in oxidative steam reforming of methane over Ni0.2Mg0.8O, Rh(0.035)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O, and Rh(0.035)/MgO [75]. In these experiments, W/F was changed from higher to lower, then reverted to higher values. Hysteresis of catalytic performance with respect to W/F decreasing and increasing in oxidative steam reforming of methane was observed over Ni0.2Mg0.8O. This behavior is reflected by deactivation due to oxidation under low W/F conditions. In particular, the methane conversion was decreased from about 100% to 40% when the W/F was decreased from 0.4 to 0.2ghmol−1. When the state of catalyst is unchanged, conversion is proportional to W/F in the low conversion range. The decrease of the methane conversion on Ni0.2Mg0.8O is too steep, indicating that the state of catalyst drastically changed by the oxidation. On the other hand, hysteresis was not observed on Rh(0.035)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O and Rh(0.035)/MgO. Another important point is that Rh(0.035)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O showed much higher conversion than Ni0.2Mg0.8O and Rh(0.035)/MgO, particularly at low W/F values. One additive effect of Rh is to enhance the reduction degree of Ni species in Ni0.2Mg0.8O. However, the enhancement of the reduction degree cannot explain the great difference in the activity at low W/F. Similar behavior was also observed in the case of Pt and Pd addition [74]. The results indicate that the synergy between Rh and NiO–MgO can contribute to inhibition of oxidation deactivation even at the shorter contact time. Fig. 11 shows the dependence of methane conversion in oxidative steam reforming of methane over Ni(0.9) and Pt(0.2)/Ni(0.9) supported on γ-Al2O3 as a function of the temperature of thermocouple (T TC) [87]. In the activity test, after the catalyst was reduced in H2 flow at 1123K for 0.5h, T TC was first decreased from 1123 to 773K; subsequently it was increased from 773 to 1123K. In the profile of T TC decreasing over Ni(0.9), methane conversion decreased drastically at T TC =923K, which is due to the oxidation of active Ni species. It dropped to about zero when T TC was below 873K, where Ni catalyst lost its methane reforming and combustion activity. On the other hand, in the profile of T TC increasing, the catalytic activity of Ni(0.9) was not recovered until 1023K. When T TC was beyond 1023K, methane conversion increased gradually, however it did not reach the same conversion level as in the profile of T TC decreasing. An important point on Ni(0.9) is that methane conversion showed the severe hysteresis with respect to T TC decreasing and increasing. In contrast, in the case of Pt(0.2)/Ni(0.9) catalyst, the hysteresis was not observed; the behaviors in the profiles of increasing and decreasing temperature were almost identical. The addition of Pt was also effective for resistance to the oxidation of Ni even when the reaction temperature was rather low. The addition of noble metals to Ni catalysts enhanced the resistance to the deactivation by oxidation drastically under higher oxygen partial pressure, shorter contact time, and lower reaction temperature, as a result, the conversion was enhanced. In the oxidative steam reforming, the catalyst near the catalyst inlet is oxidized because O2 is present in the gas phase, and this oxidized zone becomes larger at higher oxygen partial pressure, shorter contact time, and lower reaction temperature. On the other hand, the amount of the reduced catalyst in the downstream becomes smaller, and methane conversion decreased because methane reforming is catalyzed by the reduced catalyst. The amount of the catalyst in the oxidized and reduced states is determined by the oxidation rate and the reduction rate of the catalysts and the addition of noble metals to Ni catalysts can enhance the reduction rate, as is suggested from the temperature-programmed reduction. A synergy effect of noble metals and Ni in the oxidative steam reforming is interpreted as due to the high activity of Ni metal species whose state is maintained by the presence of noble metals with high reducibility. The enhanced resistance to the Ni oxidation by the addition of noble metals is also reported by Nagaoka et al. [88] where autothermal reforming of methane was carried out at very high space velocities (1.7×102 to 1.2×104 lg−1 h−1) and at a cycle of temperature (1073–773–1073K). The activity of Ni/MgAl was completely lost at 773K at very high space velocities due to the oxidation of Ni and was not recovered even if the temperature was increased to 1073K. The oxidation of Ni was suppressed efficiently by the addition of small amounts of Rh (Ni/Rh=49) by co-precipitation method. Two explanations of the role of Rh in suppressing the oxidation of Ni are suggested. One is related to the high catalytic activity due to the larger amount of metals exposed, which leads to more reductive atmosphere. The other possibility is the H2 spillover from Rh to the NiRh alloy particles. 4.2 Suppression of hot spot formation In the case of the conventional steam reforming of methane, the heat transfer from the outside limits the productivity of synthesis gas. On the other hand, the feeding rate of the reactants in the oxidative steam reforming of methane can be higher than that in steam reforming. This is because the oxidative steam reforming of methane can be an internal heat supplying system, and this can be connected to much higher productivity of the synthesis gas. However, oxidative steam reforming of methane under a higher feeding rate has a problem of hot spot formation near the catalyst bed inlet, because the hot spot increases the catalyst temperature and this can cause the catalyst deactivation via sintering and aggregation of metal particles. Catalyst development for the suppression of hot spot formation contributes to higher productivity. In order to evaluate the suppressing effect of the hot spot formation, one must measure the temperature gradient in the catalyst bed during the oxidative steam reforming of methane. Fig. 12 shows an example of the experimental setup using IR thermography [111]. It has been found that the temperature gradient of Pt and Rh was much smaller than that of Ni catalyst in oxidative steam reforming of methane [112,113]. This behavior is related to the oxygen affinity of Rh and Pt being lower than that of Ni; the small temperature gradient in the catalyst bed is explained by the overlap of the combustion reaction zone with the reforming reaction zone, as explained below. On the other hand, although Pd has low oxygen affinity, it showed a larger temperature gradient than Ni catalyst because of the very low reforming activity of Pd catalysts. Fig. 13 shows the effect of loading amount on the bed temperature in the oxidative steam reforming of methane over the Ni and Pt monometallic catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 [79]. In the case of Ni catalysts, the highest bed temperature is insensitive to the Ni loading amount, indicating that the hot spot cannot be suppressed by varying the Ni loading. In the case of Pt catalysts, considering the high cost and limited availability of Pt, a decreased loading amount is desired. However, it is difficult to obtain high activity and high resistance to hot spot formation on the monometallic noble-metal catalysts with a very small loading amount. One of the strategies of catalyst development for oxidative reforming of methane with high resistance to hot spot formation is the combination of high reforming activity of Ni with high reducibility of a small amount of Pt [93,94]. In addition, an intermetallic compound and alloy have been known to form between Pt and Ni, which is caused by their strong interaction. The structure of the bimetallic particles can be influenced by the preparation method as described above, so the effects of noble-metal addition by two different preparation methods can be compared. Fig. 14 shows the catalyst bed temperature profile in oxidative steam reforming of methane over Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6), Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6), Ni(2.6), and Pt(0.1) supported on γ-Al2O3 at the same contact time [79]. A very high temperature region near the catalyst bed inlet and much lower temperature region in the downstream were observed over Ni(2.6). This large temperature gradient is caused by separation of the combustion and reforming reaction zones, as explained below. Pt(0.1) exhibited a flatter temperature profile than Ni(2.6). However, the temperature at the inlet was rather high. The temperature profile on Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6) was similar to that on Ni(2.6), which indicates that the additive effect of Pt introduced by the co-impregnation method is small. In contrast, the temperature on Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) is much lower than that for the other three catalysts, which means that the additive effect of Pt introduced by the sequential impregnation method is remarkable, in spite of the lower activity in the steam reforming of methane without the addition of oxygen (Table 4). The additive effect of Pt can be strongly dependent on the preparation method and the structure of bimetallic particles. We have reported that the temperature profile of Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) in the oxidative steam reforming of methane was almost the same during 8h [86]. In addition, the FTIR spectrum of CO adsorption on the used Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) for 8h was similar to that on the fresh catalyst [86]. These results indicate the stability of Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6). The structure of the Pt–Ni bimetallic particles on Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) can be stable under the reaction conditions. On the other hand, the surface Pt atoms may be incorporated into the bulk because of the strong interaction between Pt and Ni. It may be expected that a well-mixed structure like the bimetallic particles prepared by the co-impregnation method is more thermodynamically stable than the segregated structure. At present, the activation energy in the conversion of segregated structure to well-mixed structure is thought be so high that the metastable segregated structure can be maintained. One reason for the high activation energy can be that the metal bonding radius of Pt is larger than that of Ni. Fig. 15 shows the highest catalyst bed temperature and methane conversion in oxidative steam reforming of methane over Pt–Ni, Pd–Ni, monometallic Pt, Pd, and Ni catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 [23]. In fact, Pd(0.05) showed low methane conversion and high bed temperature; this result indicates that Pd(0.05) has high combustion activity and low reforming activity. The highest bed temperature on Pd(0.05)+Ni(2.6) was almost identical to that on Ni(2.6). In contrast, the highest bed temperature on Pd(0.05)/Ni(2.6) was much lower than those on Ni(2.6), Pd(0.05) and Pd(0.05)+Ni(2.6). Similar behavior of Pt–Ni and Pd–Ni in oxidative steam reforming of methane in terms of the superiority of the sequential impregnation method suggests that the additive effect of Pt and Pd is caused by surface segregation structure and high reducibility, not by catalytic properties of Pt and Pd themselves such as high combustion activity of Pd metal. The Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) showed a little higher resistance to hot spot formation than Pd(0.05)/Ni(2.6), and this can be interpreted by the different metal particle size of 5.0nm for Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) (Table 4) and 8.1nm for Pd(0.05)/Ni(2.6) [80]. The effect of metal particle size on the hot spot formation is discussed in the topics of α-Al2O3 supported catalysts. Comparison between the sequential and co-impregnation catalysts indicates that higher surface ratio of Pt or Pd to Ni is connected to higher resistance to the catalyst oxidation and hot spot formation. On the other hand, the order of the highest bed temperature was Rh(0.05)<Rh(0.05)/Ni(2.6)<Rh(0.05)+Ni(2.6)≈Ni(2.6) [80]. Except for Rh(0.05), the tendency was similar to that of Pd containing Ni(2.6)-based catalysts. The addition of Rh was effective to the suppression of hot spot formation on Ni; however, the performance of the monometallic Rh catalyst was higher than those of the bimetallic catalysts. This can be due to the superiority of Rh itself, which is known to be very effective for the catalytic partial oxidation of methane at much shorter contact times [114–117]. In order to elucidate the suppression mechanism of the hot spot formation, it is necessary to understand the state of the catalysts near the catalyst bed inlet. Here, the temperature-programmed reduction profiles of the catalyst near the inlet and outlet were obtained separately [87]. The state of the catalysts near the catalyst bed outlet is also important as a reference because all the catalysts are in the reduced state at the high partial pressure of synthesis gas and in the absence of oxygen. In this experiment, the catalyst was purged with Ar after the reaction (CH4/H2O/O2/Ar=40/30/20/10, W/F =0.16ghmol−1, 1123K, W =0.08g), and then cooled rapidly from the reaction temperature to room temperature. Then the catalysts at the bed inlet and outlet were divided carefully. The amount of the divided catalysts was 0.01g. Judging from the catalyst bed temperature profiles (Fig. 14), we found that the size of the high temperature zone was as large as a quarter of the catalyst bed, where the total amount of the catalyst was 0.08g. Fig. 16 shows the temperature-programmed reduction profiles of the catalysts near the bed inlet and outlet [87]. The lower temperature peak (650–760K) is assignable to NiO, which interacts weakly with the Al2O3 surface [118]. The higher temperature peak at 1150K is attributed to the reduction of NiAl2O4 compound [119,120], which can be formed by a solid-state reaction between NiO and Al2O3. The respective H2 consumption values for reduction of NiO and NiAl2O4 were determined as 70% and 29% on Ni(2.6) at the inlet, indicating that almost all of the Ni species at the catalyst bed inlet were oxidized during the reaction. On the other hand, in the case of Ni(2.6) at the bed outlet, the peak at 470K is attributable to the reduction of adsorbed oxygen species on the metallic Ni surface, where the catalysts were oxidized during the sample transfers from the reactor to the TPR cell. The TPR result at the outlet indicates that the metallic Ni species were present on the catalyst at the outlet under the reaction condition. The amount of H2 consumption in the lower temperature peak was decreased to 59% on Pt(0.1)+Ni(2.6) at the bed inlet. In addition, the maximum reduction of Ni oxide was observed at 630K, which is about 40K lower than the reduction of Ni on Ni(2.6). An important point is that the reduction peak shifted to a much lower temperature region (530–610K) on Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) at the catalyst bed inlet, which corresponded to 44% of the amount of Ni. These results indicate that the addition of Pt by sequential impregnation method greatly increased the amount of reduced Ni at the catalyst bed inlet, even in the presence of gas-phase O2 during oxidative steam reforming of methane. The surface Pt atoms segregated on the surface of Pt–Ni bimetallic particles on Pt(0.1)/Ni(2.6) gave high reducibility to the catalyst and the high resistance to the catalyst oxidation. Fig. 17 illustrates the hot spot formation mechanism on Ni catalysts and the suppression mechanism of hot spot formation on Ni catalysts modified with Pt and Pd [23]. A large temperature gradient over Ni catalysts in oxidative steam reforming of methane was observed. Most Ni species were oxidized in the presence of oxygen at the catalyst bed inlet because the rate of Ni oxidation by O2 is much higher than the rate of reduction of oxidized Ni species with reducing agents like CH4, CO, and H2. Consequently, the oxidized Ni species loses reforming activity and only has combustion activity. Therefore, at the catalyst bed inlet, only the exothermic reaction can proceed, which increases the catalyst bed temperature. On the other hand, in the region with no oxygen at the catalyst bed outlet, the Ni species can be maintained in the metallic state; the Ni species presents the reforming activity. In this reaction zone, only the endothermic reaction can proceed and the catalyst bed temperature decreases, which can result in a large temperature gradient. In contrast, on the Pt/Ni and Pd/Ni catalysts, the ratio of reduced to oxidized species can be much higher in the presence of oxygen because of the modification effect. In particular, the reduced species can also serve as the active site for methane reforming as well as combustion, even in the presence of oxygen. The reforming reaction can contribute to a temperature decrease at the catalyst bed inlet. Here, the exothermic heat by the combustion reaction can be transferred to the endothermic reforming reaction directly at the same region in the catalyst bed and at the same catalyst surface, which is called “direct heat supplying system”. The highest bed temperature in the oxidative steam reforming is influenced by the metal particle size on Ni/α-Al2O3 [121]. In order to evaluate the effect of the Ni metal particle size of monometallic Ni catalysts, we prepared and tested the Ni catalysts with different precursors, because it has been reported that different precursors (chloride, nitrate, acetate) brought about different metal dispersion values [121]. The Ni/α-Al2O3 catalysts with lower dispersion gave the higher bed temperature; this can be explained by lower reforming activity of the catalysts with lower dispersion. The addition of Pd and Pt to Ni/α-Al2O3 catalysts also affects the metal particle size. Therefore, it is necessary to compare the data including the size of bimetallic particles. Here, the relation between the highest bed temperature in oxidative steam reforming of methane and the average particle size estimated from H2 adsorption amount over various catalysts is shown in Fig. 18 [84]. The tendency that the catalyst with smaller metal particles is more effective to the suppression of hot spot formation was also observed on almost all the bimetallic catalysts. The addition of Pd is totally more effective to the decrease of the highest bed temperature than Pt, and it is concluded that the co-impregnation method using PdCl2 and Ni(NO3)2 is most effective, and the smaller loading amount of Pd is also more effective. The preparation method by sequential impregnation gave larger average metal particles size and this tendency can be caused by the surface ratio of Pt or Pd to Ni being higher than that by co-impregnation method, probably because the interaction between noble metals and α-Al2O3 is weaker than that between Ni and α-Al2O3. Smaller metal particle size is more favorable, and at the same time, higher surface ratio of Pt or Pd to Ni is also more favorable. However, a higher surface ratio of Pt or Pd tends to increase the metal particle size. Therefore, the additive amount should be optimized. It is thought that smaller metal particle size and higher surface ratio of a noble metal are more compatible in the case of Pd+Ni compared to the case of Pt+Ni. An important point is that Pd is more effective than Pt considering the particle size of bimetallic particles. Based on the results, Ni/α-Al2O3 catalysts modified with various noble metals using corresponding noble-metal chloride precursors were prepared by the co-impregnation method and tested in the oxidative steam reforming of methane, as shown in Fig. 19 [83]. The addition of a larger amount of noble-metal changes the metal particle size: the increase was observed in the case of Ru, Rh, and Pd, and the decrease was observed in the case of Ir, Pt, and Au. The reason for the different tendency has not been elucidated and further investigation is necessary, although it may be affected by the ionic state of precursor salts such as anions ([IrCl6]2−, [PtCl6]2−, [AuCl4]−) and cations (Ru3+, Rh3+, Pd2+). The highest bed temperature decreased with decreasing metal particle size over the monometallic Ni catalysts, as mentioned above. Similar tendency was obtained on Ir+Ni, Pt+Ni, and Pd+Ni catalysts. It is characteristic that the monometallic noble-metal catalysts such as Ir(0.14), Pt(0.14), and Pd(0.07) have much lower activity in oxidative steam reforming, which suggests that the main active species on Ir+Ni, Pt+Ni, and Pd+Ni can be Ni. On the other hand, a different tendency was observed on Ru+Ni and Rh+Ni catalysts, and the corresponding monometallic catalysts such as Ru(0.07) and Rh(0.07) have higher activity in oxidative steam reforming. Therefore, the main active species on Ru+Ni and Rh+Ni can be Ru and Rh, and these noble metals have higher resistance to hot spot formation. The temperature decrease can be explained by compensation of particle size increase with larger amount of noble-metal addition in the case of Ru+Ni and Rh+Ni catalysts. In the case of Au+Ni, the addition of larger amount of Au decreased the particle size, but increased the bed temperature. This can be due to very low activity of Au itself. From the comparison, we conclude that Pd is the most effective among noble metals. The temperature measurement system using thermocouples was applied to the oxidative reforming of methane with CO2 over similar bimetallic catalysts. The result indicates that the sequential impregnation Pt/Ni catalyst is more effective to the suppression of the hot spot formation than the co-impregnation Pt+Ni catalyst in the oxidative reforming with CO2 when a small amount of Pt is added to Ni catalysts [93,94,113]. The effect of noble-metal addition on the catalyst bed temperature in the partial oxidation of methane was reported by Basile et al. [56,70] where IR thermography was also used to monitor the surface temperature. In their studies, the partial oxidation of methane was carried out under autothermal conditions without external heat supply. The temperature at the beginning of the catalyst bed is found to be Rh/Ni>Ni, while the temperature at the exit of the catalyst bed is this opposite. This is because Ni is deactivated in oxygen rich conditions by the oxidation of Ni metals, while the presence of Rh in the Rh/Ni catalyst prevents the Ni oxidation and consequently gives higher activity in the oxidation conditions. 5 Suppression of carbon formation In the GTL and methanol synthesis process, the industrial production of synthesis gas by the reforming of natural gas under pressurized conditions is preferable because the natural gas has high pressure underground and the reactions of Fischer–Tropsch and methanol synthesis are also carried out under pressurized conditions. Methane reforming to synthesis gas under more pressurized conditions can save the energy for the compression of the synthesis gas more significantly. Therefore, the evaluation of the catalytic performance under pressurized conditions has been important. For example, a large amount of carbon was deposited under the pressured dry reforming of methane on the catalyst with high resistance to the coke deposition in the dry reforming at atmospheric pressure [122]. In particular, the rate of carbon deposition in the methane reforming increased drastically with increasing the reaction pressure as reported previously [122–128], and this can be connected to the catalyst deactivation. Oxidative steam reforming of methane was carried out in a horizontal fixed-bed flow reaction system under the pressurized condition [75]. A quartz tube (inner diameter, 4.4mm) inside a stainless steel tube (inner diameter, 7.4mm) was used as the reactor, and the quartz tube was sealed by a silicon rubber gasket. At the outlet of the catalyst bed, the reaction temperature was monitored by a thermocouple, which was inserted into a thin quartz tube. Catalysts were reduced with hydrogen at atmospheric pressure at 1073K for 0.5h in each experiment. The partial pressure ratio of reactants was CH4/H2O/O2 =2/1.5/1. Steam reforming (CH4/H2O=1/1) and dry reforming (CH4/CO2 =1/1) of methane were also carried out in the same apparatus. The total pressure was 1.0MPa; 30mg of catalyst was used for each experiment. The length of the catalyst bed was about 4mm. Contact time W/F was 0.43ghmol−1, where methane conversion did not reach the equilibrium level in order to evaluate the catalyst deactivation from the decrease of methane conversion. In all these experiments, all the oxygen was converted, and the water gas shift reaction reached the equilibrium. Therefore, higher methane conversion is related to high CO selectivity and lower H2/CO ratio. Here, the deactivation rate is defined as follow; ((CH4 conversion at 0.5h)−(CH4 conversion at 8h))/(CH4 conversion at 0.5h)×100%. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for the estimation of carbon amount was carried out by using a Shimadzu DTG-60 apparatus. The analysis was done with 10mg of catalysts under flowing air (20cm3 min−1) at 15Kmin−1 heating rate. The amount of carbon was estimated from the exothermic weight loss between 800K and 1000K. Table 5 lists the properties of noble-metal added NiO–MgO solid solution catalysts and their catalytic performances in oxidative steam reforming of methane under pressurized conditions [72–75]. It is characteristic that Rh(0.035)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O, Rh(0.035)/MgO, Pt(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O, and Pt(0.1)/MgO gave almost no carbon deposition and very low deactivation rate. Comparing with the behavior of Ni0.2Mg0.8O without the modification of Rh and Pt, the addition of Rh and Pt to NiO–MgO solid solution is effective for the inhibition of carbon deposition, which originates from the properties of Rh and Pt themselves because there is no coke and no deactivation of Rh/MgO and Pt/MgO. The behavior of Pd-added Ni0.2Mg0.8O solid solution catalysts was different from that of Rh- and Pt-added catalysts, and low resistance to carbon deposition of Pd/MgO can explain the difference. Fig. 20 shows a relationship between carbon deposition and deactivation rate in oxidative steam reforming of methane over Pd/Ni0.2Mg0.8O, Ni0.2Mg0.8O, and Pd/MgO [23]. An important point is that Pd(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O has high resistance to coke deposition and no catalyst deactivation, although the coke deposition and the catalyst deactivation were clearly observed on Pd(0.1)/MgO and Ni0.2Mg0.8O. Table 5 also lists the catalytic performance of Pd/MgO with various Pd loading amounts [73]. The amount of carbon deposition and the deactivation rate increased with increasing the loading amount of Pd. On the other hand, the loading amount of Pd should be optimized because Pd/Ni0.2Mg0.8O with Pd content <0.1wt% and >0.15wt% has lower resistance to coke formation and the catalyst deactivation. The differences in metal particle size are quite small, and the resistance to carbon deposition cannot be explained using the differences in the metal particle size. The interaction between Pd and Ni species is thought to contribute to the suppression of carbon formation. The structure of Pd–Ni bimetallic particles and surface composition can affect the performance. The similar tendency was observed on the system of Pd(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8Al2O4 [81]. On the basis of the catalyst characterization, Pd clusters embedded into Ni metal particles are formed on Pd/Ni0.2Mg0.8O catalysts. The promoting effect of Pd addition can be also influenced by the size of embedded Pd clusters, and large Pd clusters lose the resistance to coke formation through its synergy with Ni. Fig. 21 shows the relation between carbon deposition and the deactivation rate in steam, dry, and the oxidative steam reforming over Pd(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O, Pd(0.1)/MgO, and Ni0.2Mg0.8O [23]. The amount of carbon deposition was in the order of dry, steam, and oxidative reforming of methane. The carbon amount on Pd(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O was smaller than that on Ni0.2Mg0.8O and Pd(0.1)/MgO, although Pd(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O gave about 10wt% carbon in dry and steam reforming. However, it should be noted that Pd(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O can suppress carbon deposition in oxidative reforming of methane. The oxidative steam reforming of methane consists of methane combustion on the catalyst near the catalyst bed inlet and methane reforming with steam and CO2 on the catalyst at the downstream, where CO2 and a part of steam are the products of the combustion reaction. Therefore, it seems that the carbon was formed on the catalyst at the downstream, but no carbon was observed. This can be explained by the catalyst bed temperature. In the case of methane reforming with steam and CO2, the catalyst bed temperature is lower than the temperature of the bed outlet at which the thermocouple is located. In contrast, the catalyst bed temperature is higher than the temperature bed outlet judging from the IR thermographical observation as indicated above. The rate of carbon deposition is sensitive to the catalyst temperature, and the carbon deposition is more favorable at lower temperature [129]. The resistance to coke deposition in oxidative steam reforming is related to the higher catalyst temperature. It has been reported that the Ni–Au catalyst showed no deactivation in the steam reforming of n-butane and almost no coke deposition. This performance was explained by the decrease in the stability of the adsorbed carbon atom and the increase in its reactivity with adsorbed oxygen by the formation of the Ni–Au surface alloy [130]. This explanation is applicable to the effect of the modification with small amounts of noble metals on the suppression of coke formation in the oxidative steam reforming of methane under pressurized conditions. 6 Catalyst activation by the reactants under mild conditions: self-activation behavior The interaction of Ni species with support materials such as Al2O3 and MgO is much stronger than that of noble metals, and this strong interaction can be related to low reducibility of the supported Ni catalysts. The Ni species on Al2O3 can form NiAl2O4 with low reducibility. In particular, the interaction between Ni and MgO is so strong that the oxidized Ni and MgO are easily converted to NiO–MgO solid solution in any composition by the solid reaction. Since MgO is an effective support and additive in order to suppress the coke deposition [105,106,129,131], MgO has been utilized in the catalysts for the methane reforming. On the other hand, the reducibility of Ni species is decreased significantly by the addition of relatively small amounts of MgO to the Ni catalyst [132]. NiO–MgO solid solution with low Ni content required H2 reduction at 1123K [105]. In a practical process, it is difficult to reduce the catalysts with pure H2. The catalyst should be reduced and activated by the reactants, for example, methane, oxygen, and steam in the case of the oxidative steam reforming of methane. Fig. 22 shows the dependence of Pt addition on the catalyst activation in oxidative steam reforming of methane over Ni0.2Mg0.8O solid solution [78]. In this experiment, the reactant gas (CH4/H2O/O2 =2/1.5/1) was introduced onto the catalyst without H2 pretreatment. At first, the catalyst was heated at 773K under Ar flowing, and then the reactant gases (CH4 +H2O+O2) for oxidative steam reforming of methane were introduced at 773K. The performance was observed at the reaction temperature for 30min. After 30min, the temperature was increased to 823K. Furthermore, the catalyst was heated stepwise up to 1073K by 50K steps. At each temperature, the performance was observed for 30min. In the case of Pt(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O, methane conversion was 25% and the main carbon-containing product was CO2 at 773K. This result indicates that only the methane combustion reaction proceeded. At a reaction temperature higher than 773K, methane conversion was beyond 25%, and it increased with increasing the reaction temperature. This behavior indicates that the reforming reaction proceeded and that the synthesis gas was formed under these reaction conditions. Methane conversion over Pt(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O increased smoothly with increasing the temperature. On the other hand, in the case of Pt(0.1)/MgO, in the range of 773–973K, methane conversion was much lower than 25%, this indicates that Pt(0.1)/MgO has low activity of methane combustion and reforming. At 1023K, methane conversion reached about 50%, although it was lower than that over Pt(0.1)/Ni0.2Mg0.8O. In addition, in the case of Ni0.2Mg0.8O in all the temperature ranges, methane conversion did not reach 25%. This means that Ni0.2Mg0.8O cannot be activated by CH4 +H2O+O2. From this comparison, we conclude that the addition of Pt to Ni0.2Mg0.8O enables the catalyst activation under mild conditions such as low temperature [78]. The addition of Rh and Pd to NiO–MgO solid solution catalysts also enables the catalyst activation by the reactant gas in the oxidative steam reforming of methane like the case of Pt addition [74,75]. The activation of Pd/Ni0:2Mg0:8Al2O4 in the oxidative steam reforming of methane is facilitated by the presence of Pd [81,82]. The self-activation of noble metal–Ni catalysts is influenced by various factors such as the type of noble metal, loading amount, precursor, and preparation method. Fig. 23 shows the effect of the doping amount of Pt, Rh, and Ru on the self-activation of Ni0.5Mg2.5(Al)O in the steam reforming of methane [61]. The reaction was conducted in a CH4/H2O/N2 (50/100/25mlmin−1) gas mixture at 973K for 180min, after heating the catalyst from room temperature to 973K in N2 gas flow. All Pt/Ni0.5Mg2.5(Al)O exhibited high CH4 conversion just after starting the reaction, although Pt(0.05)/Ni0.5Mg2.5(Al)O needed a short induction period. Rh was effective only with the doping amount above 0.10wt%, while Ru showed no reforming activity for 3h even with 0.50wt% doping. The ability of noble metals for the self-activation was deduced to be Pt>Rh≫Ru. This is probably due to the strong ability of Pt followed by Rh to promote CH4 dissociation to produce hydrogen. The order of noble metals for the self-activation in the partial oxidation of methane was also found to be Pt>Rh≫Ru [61]. Choudhary et al. [71] reported that the addition of noble metal (Pt, Pd, or Ru) to Ni/Al2O3 catalyst led to a large decrease in the light off temperature in the partial oxidation of methane, depending on the noble metal and its concentration. The light off temperature decreased in the order of Ru>Pt>Pd and decreased with increasing noble-metal concentration. Increases in both catalytic activity and CO selectivity were observed for the case of Pt or Ru addition, but substantial decreases in the activity, selectivity for CO and H2, and CO productivity were observed with increasing concentration of Pd in the catalyst. Jeong et al. [64] reported that Ru(0.5)/Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by sequentially impregnating showed higher activity than Ru(0.5)+Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by the co-impregnation in the steam reforming of methane without pre-reduction. The difference between the two Ru-promoted Ni catalysts in the degree of auto-activation was attributed to the availability of small clusters of RuO x laid over the surface of Ni-oxides for the Ru(0.5)/Ni(20)/Al2O3. Moreover, it is found that MgAl2O4-supported catalysts were more active than Al2O3-supported catalysts. Most of the Ni on the MgAl2O4 support was finely dispersed NiO clusters, while the Ni on the Al2O3 support was hard-to-reduce NiAl2O4. The presence of Ru in a highly dispersed state appears to facilitate the reduction of such Ni-oxides in the steam reforming of CH4. Dias and Assaf [91] investigated the effect of different Pd precursors on the ignition of Ni/γ-Al2O3 in the autothermal reforming of methane. In this study, the catalysts were heated to 823K in air flow, after which the methane+steam feed was started. The temperature was then raised to 873K and this temperature was maintained during the analyses; after approximately one hour, the methane+steam feed stopped and the catalyst was exposed to the air flow again at 823K. The whole process was repeated five times. It is found that Pd/Ni/Al2O3 prepared from Pd(NO3)2 precursor catalyzed the autothermal reforming of methane without the reduction pretreatment. On the other hand, the Pd/Ni/Al2O3 prepared from PdCl2 precursor only catalyzed the methane combustion. This tendency indicates that Pd/Ni/Al2O3 prepared from Pd(NO3)2 can be reduced by methane. In this case, palladium species are reduced by methane and they decompose methane to produce atomic hydrogen, which reduces nickel species and activates the catalyst. The Pd species interact strongly with the support on Pd/Ni/Al2O3 prepared from chloride by the formation of Pd x Cl y O z compounds, which cannot be reduced by methane. 7 Sustainability in the daily startup and shutdown operation In contrast to the large-scale use of reformers in the industry under typical operating conditions, the temperature varied frequently at startup and shutdown, i.e., daily startup and shutdown, for the operation in hydrogen production for polymer electrolyte fuel cells [8]. Between shutdown and startup in each DSS operation, the catalyst bed in the reformer must be purged by a sufficiently inert and an economically available gas for preserving the safety. Thus, the catalyst must be able to withstand multiple cycles under those conditions and must also tolerate operation under such unusual transient conditions without deterioration. In a study of DSS operations in steam reforming of CH4 over Ni/Mg(Al)O catalysts [32], which were prepared by using Mg(Ni)-Al hydrotalcite as the precursor, the results showed that the Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst was severely deactivated although this catalyst showed high and stable activity in the steady state CH4 reforming [133–136]. The deactivation took place by the oxidation of Ni metal not only by air but also by steam during the DSS operation. It has been reported that the addition of noble metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, and Pt) to the Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst effectively suppressed the deactivation, leading to high sustainability during the DSS-like operation [57–63]. Fig. 24 shows the results of Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O, Rh-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O, and Rh/Mg3(Al)O catalysts under the steam-purged DSS-like operation in the steam reforming of CH4 [57].
