The Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst was totally deactivated even after the first steam purging, which was due to the oxidation of Ni metal by steam. The deactivation was perfectly suppressed during the four-cycled DSS operation when 0.1wt% Rh was added to the Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst. The addition of Rh to the Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst was quite effective; even when the Rh loading decreased from 0.1 to 0.05wt%, the deactivation was completely suppressed. Further decrease in the Rh loading to 0.01wt%, however, caused the heavy deactivation after the third steam purging. In the absence of Ni, the CH4 conversion over Rh/Mg3(Al)O catalyst was low due to the low Rh loading, and the CH4 conversion continuously decreased irrespectively of the DSS cycle. It must be emphasized that Rh alone was not active enough with such small loadings and the activity of the Rh-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalysts depended mainly upon the Ni species. It is suggested that Rh keeps the reduced state during the steam purging and dissociates CH4 to form hydrogen atoms after the reaction was started again at 973K. The hydrogen atoms migrate to the oxidized Ni species by spillover and reduce them to the active Ni metals. The effects of various noble metals, i.e., Rh, Pd, Pt, and Ru addition on the sustainability of the Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst in the DSS-like operations are summarized in Fig. 25 [57,58], as the CH4 conversion at the fourth cycle versus the loading amount of each noble metal. All of Rh, Pt, and Ru are effective for enhancing the stability of the Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst even with the loading of 0.05wt%. Pd is not so effective and the loading of 0.1wt% is required for enhancing the catalyst stability in the DSS operation of CH4 steam reforming. The high durability of noble metal–Ni/Mg(Al)O catalysts in the DSS-like operation was observed not only for the fresh catalysts, but also for the severely sintered catalysts after the steam treatment. Steaming was carried out at 1173K for 10h in a mixed gas flow of H2/H2O/N2 (20/100/25mlmin−1) after pre-reduction of the catalyst at 1173K for 0.5h. It is known that such steam treatment causes a severe sintering of supported metal catalysts and is often used to evaluate the catalyst life [137–142]. Fig. 26 shows the results of DSS SR of methane over Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O and Ru(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O before and after steaming [59]. The Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst was deactivated by steaming and showed a total deactivation just after the first steam purging. On the other hand, the Ru(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst showed a stable activity during DSS SR of methane even after steaming. Interestingly, the time course of methane conversion during the DSS operation revealed that Ru(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O was rather stabilized after steaming; a sudden decrease in methane conversion observed just after each steam purging disappeared and methane conversion became rather constant throughout the DSS operation after steaming. A similar result was obtained over Rh(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O and Pt(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O after steaming. Table 6 shows the sizes of Ni particles on the Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O, Ru-, Rh-, and Pt-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalysts before and after steaming, and after steaming followed by DSS SR of methane [59–61]. After the steaming, the sizes of Ni particles on all catalysts significantly increased, indicating an occurring of heavy sintering of Ni particles. Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O exhibited no Ni metal reflection in the XRD after the DSS SR of methane. This indicates that Ni was totally oxidized during DSS SR of methane. It must be noticed that, on noble metal (0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalysts after steaming, the sizes of Ni particles substantially decreased after DSS SR and returned close to the original value. All these catalysts exhibited sustainable activity during the DSS SR of methane. Such prominent catalytic performance of the noble metal–Ni/Mg(Al)O system is likely to be achieved by the continuous self-regeneration of active Ni metal species. Ni2+ ions in Mg(Ni, Al)O periclase were reduced by hydrogen spillover from noble metal to form fine Ni0 particles on the surface of periclase. Conversely, surface Ni0 particles were oxidized to Ni2+ by steam and incorporated into the periclase. Such reduction-oxidation between Ni0 and Ni2+ on/in Mg(Ni,Al)O periclase aided by hydrogen spillover on noble metal or noble metal–Ni alloy effectively contributed to the regeneration of activity on the noble metal–Ni/Mg(Al)O catalysts during the SRM DSS operation. A scheme of the self-regenerative activity of Ru-Ni/Mg(Al)O is shown in Fig. 27 [59]. Fig. 28 compares the activities of Ru(0.1)- and Pt(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O in the DSS SR of CH4 under air or air–steam combined purging [61]. Under air purging, both catalysts showed high and stable activity in the DSS SR of CH4 (Fig. 28A). This indicates that air, or oxygen, as purging gas did not oxidize Ni on either catalyst like the case of steam during DSS operation. However, the combination of air and steam as purging gas quickly deactivated Ru(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst; both combined purging of air–steam-air and steam-air–steam totally deactivated the catalyst after the first purging (Fig. 28B). On the contrary, Pt(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst was not deactivated by such combined purging (Fig. 28B). This indicates that Pt addition is more effective than Ru addition for the catalyst sustainability under air–steam combined purging. In addition to SR, ATR is also considered as a hopeful candidate for the production of hydrogen for polymer electrolyte fuel cells. Fig. 29 compares the activities of Pt- and Ru-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalysts in the DSS ATR of methane under steam purging [61]. Ru(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O catalyst exhibited significant deactivation just after the first steam purging. Even when Ru addition was increased to 0.5wt%, the activity decreased significantly after the first steam purging. This result indicates that Ru-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O was not suitable for the DSS ATR of methane. Contrarily, Pt(0.1)-Ni0.5/Mg2.5(Al)O was sustainable enough for the steam-purged DSS ATR of CH4. We conclude that Pt-Ni/Mg(Al)O is more sustainable than Ru-Ni/Mg(Al)O not only in the air–steam-purged DSS SR of methane but also in the steam-purged DSS ATR of methane. 8 Conclusions The addition of a small amount of noble metals to Ni catalysts significantly modifies the properties of Ni metal particles by the formation of noble metal–Ni bimetallic particles. By carefully choosing the preparation method, one can obtain bimetallic particles with different structures. In particular, the addition of a small amount of noble metals to γ-Al2O3-supported Ni catalysts by the sequential impregnation method leads to the formation of segregated noble-metal atoms on the surface of the bimetallic particles, while the co-impregnation method results in a well-mixed structure. Bimetallic particles with noble metals enriched on the surface are also formed on other supported catalysts such as α-Al2O3-supported catalysts and NiO–MgO. Compared to monometallic Ni catalysts, noble metal–modified Ni catalysts exhibit superior performances in the methane reforming reactions, i.e., high activity, suppression of Ni oxidation and hot spot formation, high resistance to carbon deposition, and self-activation with the reactant gas. In addition, noble metal–modified Ni/Mg(Al)O catalysts show high stability and regenerative activity in the DSS-like operation of methane reforming. The improved performance of Ni catalysts modified with noble metals can be attributed to the synergic effect between noble metal and Ni by the formation of noble metal–Ni bimetallic particles. Functions of each noble metal in the modification of Ni are summarized. The Pt modification tends to promote the Ni reduction connecting to the suppression of hot spot formation, self-activation, and sustainability in the DSS operation, although the contribution of Pt modification on the steam reforming activity was small. The Pt modification also gives the resistance to coke deposition. The promoting effect of Pd on the reduction is similar to the case of Pt. The properties of Pd itself are high combustion activity and low reforming activity; however, Pd–Ni catalysts suppressed the hot spot formation effectively. In order to get high resistance to coke deposition with Pd modification, the additive amount should be optimized carefully. The Rh modification tends to enhance the catalyst reducibility connecting to self-activation and sustainability in the DSS operation. Since Rh itself has high reforming activity and high resistance to hot spot formation, high performance of Rh-Ni catalysts can be caused by the properties of Rh itself. Small amount of Rh modification is also effective to the suppression of coke deposition. The effect of Ru modification can be similar to that of Rh. The effect on the suppression of the coke deposition was not investigated; however, the suppressing effect of Ru can be promising. Other noble metals such as Ir and Au were also effective to the promotion in the catalyst reducibility; however, the effect is not so remarkable as that of Pt, Pd, Rh, and Ru. Modification effect with noble metals is also influenced by the bimetallic particles and the surface composition which are dependent on preparation method, the type of noble metal, and its combination with support material. The modification of Ni catalysts with a small amount of noble metals is demonstrated to be a promising approach to design catalysts with excellent performances for the methane reforming. coredata.dc:description: Nickel is an effective component for the steam reforming of methane in terms of the catalytic activity and the catalyst cost. When Ni catalysts are applied to dry reforming, oxidative reforming, and catalytic partial oxidation, it is necessary to add the properties of high resistance to oxidation, hot spot formation, and coke deposition, to the Ni catalysts. An efficient method for giving these properties while considering the catalyst cost is the modification of Ni metal particles with small amounts of noble metals. An important point is that preparation methods can affect the structure of noble metal–Ni bimetallic particles, which is connected to the catalytic performances. The additive effects of noble metals on the catalytic performances are summarized in terms of activity, suppression of Ni oxidation, carbon formation, self-activation, and sustainability in the daily startup and shutdown operations.
coredata.dc:title: Methane reforming to synthesis gas over Ni catalysts modified with noble metals
